detailsOfAchievement: CDR Started its work in nineteen eighty three by assisting the tribal communities in forty one Villages of Jainoor and Sirpur mandals in Adilabad Dist in Identifying and executing drought relief works CDR also was instrumental in preparation of people centered Village Development Plans that were presented to the government and later became Govt policy. CDR also assisted the tribal women in organizing the first ever Self Help Groups in Sirpur and Jainoor mandals in Adialabad district in the1991.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: With assistance from the Society for Ellmination of Rural Poverty (SERP) under the scheduled caste sub plan, CDR helped the mothers in 10 districts run 1160 ECE schools during the financial year 2014-15 a total of 17,270 children were enrolled.

CDR continued with its Our Village - Our School Programme during the 2015-16 in partnership with Mandala Mahila Samakya and Society for Elimination of Rural Poverty SERP, covered total 10 districts in Telangana 8 and Andhra Pradesh 2 Enrollment total Schools 1111 childerns 16215

CDR is running 1065 community governed pre primary schools for tribal children in as many tribal villages in 9 erstwhile districts in Telangana State and East Godvari District of Andhra Pradesh. these include 58 schools being run for the vulnerable kondareddy trive children in Marredumalli Mandal in East Godavari District of Andhra Pradesh to conducts training for teachers and monthers of school committees, Please visit www.ceedeer.org for more information

Govt of Teangana stopped all programmes undertaken by SERP due to " paucity of funds". The Pre Primary School programme was also "temporarily suspended". CDR invited like minded donors to support 58 Pre Primary Schools in East Godavari district for the children of vulnerable Konda Reddy tribe in Maredumilli mandal. It entered into a MOU with the TW dept of Govt of AP and raised funds by Training Teachers. These funds were used for the PP schools.
Grants were neither asked nor given to CDR by any Govt dept . It continued to raise funds through training oftribal teachers of the ITDA schools.

detailsOfAchievement: Major Activities and Achievements â€¢Facilitated a Personal Relation ship centers at the government hospitals for easing the process of delivering medial certificate to the persons with disabil-ities. â€¢Initiated Grievance Help Desk Centers for forwarding grievance of the persons with disabilities to the district collector for perusal. â€¢Organized workshop with APIDC, chairman to provide opportunities of jobs in private and corporate sectors. â€¢200 land and houses have been sanctioned for the persons with disabilities in Kandi Village of Sanga Reddy through constant lobby with the officials and the Honorable Chief Minister of the State. â€¢30 Residential Quarters for the Persons with disabilities, running telephone boots on pavements, has been sanctioned under VAMBY schemes of the gov-ernment at Sherilingampally through constant advocacy and lobby with the Member of Parliament, Secunderabad constituency and Municipal Corpora-tion authorities. â€¢150 Tri-cycles and wheel chairs have been distributed with the support of LANCO LIGHT Trust to the PWDs.â€¢Established Vocational Training Center for women with disability grossly benefited 350 women. â€¢Organized a District Level Sports meet for the Persons with disabilities, to mark the occasion of International Disabled Day. 280 persons with disabilities have been participated. â€¢Facilitated and performed Inter-Caste, Inter-Disability marriages of 37 poor couples.Â â€¢Organized a Human Chain involving 1116 in Medak, Ranga Reddy and Khamam District for campaigning on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities on the occasion of International Human Rights day. â€¢Organized 300 Persons with disabilities from 2 districts to participation in a CHALO DELHI CAMPAIGN, for giving representation to the government on effective implementation of the PWD Act. â€¢Organized rally and workshop with the Public Telephone Booth owners on the hike of Public call rates involving 1000 members. As a result the BSNL has withdrawn itsÂ proposal to hike the rated of Public call booths. â€¢Â 360 Unemployed youth suffering with various disabilities have been sup-ported to access livelihoods for enhancing their living standards. â€¢Â Organized workshops and seminars on NREGA Act, Right to Information Act for the youth, public representatives and activists. â€¢Provided educational support for the 45 students belonging to SC, ST and other poor families.

title: NAARI
detailsOfAchievement: Worked on a WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene) project supported by US Consulate meant to educate 500 girls on maintaining cleanliness, hygiene and using toilets responsibly. program included awareness workshops, DIY activity where we taught girls to sew their own cloth pads, Period Quiz and Games and finally handed over a Resource Material to school authorities which becomes a reference guide for girls. We ended the project with distributing cloth pads to girls from United Colors of Benetton

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Period Pride was organized to provide memorable Period Management experience to young girls of an orphanage in the city of Hyderabad. Period Pride focussed on an Awareness Session addressing 350 girls, a talk by a gynaecologist highlighting hygiene practices, nutritional needs and importance of managing Periods safely and hygienically. We organized fun story telling session and distributed hygiene kits to girls which included period essentials for them.

Menstruation forms an integral part of the WASH Project; hence it is important that girls are well trained with appropriate information about managing Menstruation safely and hygienically. They should also be well equipped with unvarying access to products, infrastructure and resources to help them manage their Periods with dignity.

title: NARSINGH SWAIN MEMORIAL TRUST
detailsOfAchievement: ACHIEVEMENTS OF NARSINGH SWAIN MEMORIAL TRUST The major achievement of the N Swain Memorial Trust is the Aakar [Shape] Asha [Hope] a Super-Specialty hospital for Reconstructive surgery with a built â€“up area of 55,000 sq.ft. in three floors on 2 acres in a strategic location on NH7, the crowded area of once Asiaâ€™s biggest housing localities that is Kukatpally, Hyderabad with an investment of around Rs. 9 crore. The one of its kind project won an award at the 2nd ISB iDiya competition in 2012. Aakar Asha is a referral Centre for Reconstructive Surgery. Apart from Reconstructive Plastic Surgery Orthopedics, Cancer and Pediatric Reconstructive surgeries are done. Specialized services like Oral and Maxillofacial surgery, Dermatology services play a significant role. The allied specialized services that are required for all round requirement of the patient like: Anesthesiologists and Pain management specialists, Physician and Neurologist, Pediatrician, General and Laparoscopic Surgeons and ENT surgeon provide the support services needed for the delightful experience of poor patients during their stay at the Hospital. A state of art Physical Rehab department completes the picture. The hospital has its own 24 x 7 Pharmacy, Diagnostic facilities (clinical pathology, biochemistry and Radiology with Color Doppler), with 3 Operating Theaters [including laminar theater as per NABH guideline], 2 ICUs and Post Op area. It has a capacity of 130 beds with 51 beds in operation of three different categories: General, Sharing and Single rooms other than ICU beds. Besides, the hospital has Dormitory facilities for accommodation of the attendants of the patient during treatment period with in the premises. The kitchen and cafeteria within the premises take care of the patients and their attendantâ€™s dietary needs and provide food for the patientâ€™s attendants. The hospital was built to take care of patient from undivided Andhra Pradesh [presently Telangana and Andhra Pradesh], where the incidence of deformities are high. However, the patient from the neighboring states are been treated with same care and sincerity. The Trust, guided by its objectives, has strived to work for the physically disabled, especially those below poverty line. Activities include creating awareness amongst stakeholders about reconstructive surgery bringing about a transformation in the lives of the physically disabled and helping to identify the beneficiaries; screening camps and reconstructive surgery camps; education and training of doctors and the public. Since 2001, we have conducted more than 30 awareness camps and have distributed literature pertaining to knowledge of physical disability and availability of treatment. No less than 20 free screening camps have been conducted wherein around 1400 persons have been screened for undergoing surgery for physical disability and 900 Physically Disabled persons have undergone reconstructive surgery free of cost since inception of the Trust. 11 Continuing Medical Education programs have been conducted, 8 of which have been the innovative Basic Surgical Skills workshops in which about 250 doctors have been trained hands on. 1 workshop on physiotherapy and a Lifesavers program for first responders have been conducted
